page.title: 04The River South Esk.(cont)
page.content: Along the banks of the Esk can be found the sites and ruins of many water-mills.Some of these were meal mills others supplied power for small industrial and agricultural enterprises. A sharp bend in the river,beleived to be partly man-made forms part of the defences of the ancient castle of Brechin. The Esk runs into the great tidal loch known as Montrose Basin.This basin is the habitat of a wide range of wild-fowl,some residents,others migratory visitors.The basin is now a nature reserve. The Esk reaches the North Sea at the town of Montrose,with wide sandy beaches to the North and a rocky headland known as Scurdie Ness to the South.
